message: Short sleep can flatten mood regulation and stress tolerance.
action: Take a 10–20 min sunlight walk.
why: Morning light is a strong circadian signal that helps align cortisol/melatonin timing and improves next-day mood stability after a short night.

message: Your body clock may be drifting later, shifting when you feel alert vs sleepy.
action: Get morning light; avoid caffeine after 2pm.
why: A later mid-sleep midpoint often tracks circadian slip; early light pulls timing earlier, and caffeine late can weaken sleep pressure.

message: Lower movement can reduce energy and mood buffering.
action: Take a 5–10 min brisk walk.
why: Short movement bursts can shift arousal and make starting the next task feel easier.

message: Extra-long sleep can leave you groggy and low-drive the next day.
action: Splash cool water + get 3 min outdoor light.
why: Light ramps wake signals; a small cold cue can reduce perceived inertia and get you moving sooner.

message: Mood often steadies when you get gentle social activation.
action: Send one short check-in message (10 words).
why: Low-effort connection reduces isolation load without requiring a big social plan.

message: Stress + short sleep can push your system into a higher-arousal state.
action: Do 3 rounds of 4–7–8 breathing.
why: Long exhales are a reliable downshift cue when stress and fatigue combine.

message: High consistency keeps routines predictable.
action: Protect the next dose time the same way you did this week.
why: Consistency removes decision-making — it becomes automatic.

message: Minor drift — make timing more predictable.
action: Tie one dose today to a fixed habit (coffee, teeth, shower).
why: Habit anchors reduce friction because you don’t have to remember — the cue does it.

message: Rebuilding consistency starts with the next dose.
action: Pick the next dose time now — simplest repeatable plan wins.
why: A single repeatable anchor beats complex plans when rebuilding.

message: Very low mood can narrow focus and kill drive.
action: Log 1 sentence: what happened in the last hour?
why: Capturing context prevents hindsight guessing and improves pattern detection.

message: Mood is below baseline — your system may be running heavier than usual.
action: Do a 2-minute reset: water + 60 seconds movement.
why: Tiny resets reduce load without demanding a big change.

message: Mood is above baseline — your brain is tagging this window as working.
action: Write what helped (one tag) so you can repeat it.
why: Recording what worked makes it easier to recreate.

message: Mood trend is dipping; accumulating load can push stress balance upward.
action: Protect one recovery block tonight (30–60 min).
why: A small predictable recovery block stabilizes the next day better than random coping.

message: A mood dip after stress can feel like motivation chemistry cooling off.
action: Complete one 2-minute quick-win task (tiny but finishable).
why: Tiny completions reduce friction and can restart momentum.

message: Mood trend is rising — momentum builds expectation and drive.
action: Keep the same anchor habit tomorrow.
why: Repeating what preceded the uptrend reinforces the pattern.

message: Stress signals are up; higher arousal can crowd out calm focus.
action: Try 60 seconds of slow-exhale breathing.
why: Long exhales can reliably downshift arousal.

message: No tags yet — tagging helps you spot what shifts mood.
action: Add one tag on your next check-in.
why: Tags improve pattern clarity and make insights more specific.

message: Sleep improves fastest when your wake time is anchored.
action: Get 2–5 minutes of outdoor light within an hour of waking.
why: Morning light strengthens circadian timing so sleep pressure and melatonin timing align more predictably.

message: Mood gets clearer when you capture context, not just a number.
action: Write one line: “Right now I feel ___ because ___.”
why: A tiny reflection improves signal quality and helps the next insight be more accurate.

message: Consistency is easier when a dose is tied to a cue.
action: Pick one daily anchor: coffee / teeth / shower / first meal.
why: If the cue is reliable, you don’t have to rely on motivation.

message: Tiny wins create momentum — even when motivation is low.
action: Do one 2-minute task now (set timer; finish one thing).
why: Small completions reduce friction and make the next step easier.

message: A 60-second reset can change the next hour.
action: Do 6 slow breaths with long exhales.
why: Breath is the fastest lever you can pull without setup.

message: Hydration can affect energy and concentration more than it feels like it should.
action: Drink a glass of water now.
why: Small hydration deficits can feel like ‘mystery fatigue’, especially with stress or heat.
